abstract.p: Fraser Shilling letter, commenting on August 22 article, says Forest Service's proposal to expand Arizona logging experiment throughout West falls short of scientific approach to fire that naturally occurs in Western forests

block.p: The Forest Service's proposal to expand the Arizona logging experiment throughout the West (front page, Aug. 22) falls short of a scientific approach to fire that naturally occurs in Western forests.
The project near Flagstaff is only several hundred acres in size and two years along.
The Forest Service's proposal to expand the Arizona logging experiment throughout the West (front page, Aug. 22) falls short of a scientific approach to fire that naturally occurs in Western forests.
The project near Flagstaff is only several hundred acres in size and two years along.
It is also useful only for the particular types of forests in that area, since all the forests in the West are not the same.
Why the rush to take a small experiment, for which the results aren't in and try it out on 40 million acres of public forests?

Maybe it has something to do with using the veneer of science and the public's desire to see something done to allow even more logging in our national forests -- logging that scientists recognize as the primary cause of the fire problems we are experiencing.
The writer is a scientist at the University of California at Davis.
